title: Sampler

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of linen, plain weave; embroidered with silk in cross, satin, stem, long and short, chain, upright gobelin, oblique gobelin, and feather stitches; laid work and couching; painted.

artist_display:
Clarissa Emerson (American, born 1808)
United States, Massachusetts, Lancaster
description: The careful planning and attention to detail of this sampler are apparent in the execution of the naturalistically rendered flowers and two figures in period dress. The underdrawing was prepared by a teacher, while the painted faces of the figures were either executed by the teacher or the maker. This is an excellent example of a piece that was executed under the direction of a private teacher or in an academy. Clarissa Emerson (1808–?) was the youngest of 12 children born to Elias (1759–1835) and Phebe Hayward Emerson (1768 [?]–1840), who were married in 1790 in Reading, Massachusetts. Elias served in the Revolutionary War, obtaining the rank of lieutenant, and he is descended from the 1636 Emerson settlers of Ipswich, Massachusetts. The verse is attributed to the hymn writer John Newton (1725–1807) or Isaac Watts (1674–1748).
medium_display: Linen, plain weave; embroidered with silk in cross, satin, stem, long and short, chain, upright Gobelin, oblique Gobelin, and feather stitches; laid work and couching; painted
inscriptions: Lancaster / Massachusetts / Jesus Permit thy gracious name to stand / As the first efforts of an infants hand / And while her fingers over this canvass move / Engage her tender heart to seek thy love / Wrought by - / Clarissa Emerson / Aged 14
credit_line: James D. Tigerman Estate; Margaret W. and John V. Farwell III Endowment Fund; Elizabeth F. Cheney Foundation Fund
publication_history:
M. Finkel & Daughter. "Samplings: A Selected Offering of Antique Samplers and Needlework." Vol. XL (2011). p. 1, cover ill.

Bolton, Ethel Stanwood and Eva Johnston Coe.  "American Samplers."  Boston:  The Massachusetts Society of the Colonial Dames of America (1921). Plate XLIX.

John Thomson Faris. "Real Stories from our History, Romance and adventure in authentic Records of the Development of the United States" (1916), as an illustrate in the story “The Heart of an Eighteenth-Century Girl.” (Faris, p. 81)
exhibition_history:
Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, Fabric of a New Nation:  American Needlework and Textiles, 1776-1840 Dec. 16, 2011–June 3, 2012, Extended: July 12-Nov. 11, 2012.

Art Institute of Chicago, PHOTOGRAPHY + FOLK ART: Looking for America in the 1930s, Sept. 21, 2019-Jan. 20, 2020.
